abstract: This Green Book provides those involved in transformer procurement with comprehensive guidance on industry best practice to avoid wrong decisions.

Foreword
CIGRE and Transformer Procurement
This Green Book provides a comprehensive guide to the transformer and reactor
procurement process, from identi ﬁcation of functional requirements to trial opera-
tion. It is intended to provide a reference for anyone involved in the procurement
process. This includes not only users and purchasers but also manufacturers and
suppliers. Each of the main steps in the procurement process is described in its own
chapter, with detailed guidance on how user expectations and requirements can best
be identi ﬁed and met. Each chapter has been written by experts in the ﬁeld and then
reviewed in detail by the editorial panel. In addition, the editorial panel has tried to
ensure a clear and consistent use of terminology.
CIGRE has long had an interest in the transformer and reactor procurement
process. The ﬁrst working group speci ﬁcally addressing this subject was 12.15 on
transformer speci ﬁcations, (CIGRE Brochure 156 2000). This working group was
followed by 12.22 on transformer design reviews, (CIGRE Brochure 204 2002).
CIGRE returned to the subject of transformer procurement some years later with
the creation of working group A2.36. This working group had the role of reviewing
the whole of the transformer procurement process. They provided an overview of the
whole process, which was used to develop the table of contents of this Green Book.
They addressed three stages of the procurement process in detail in their ﬁnal reports.
CIGRE brochure 528 (2013) was a comprehensive update of the earlier CIGRE
brochure 156 (2000). Likewise, CIGRE brochure 529 (2013) was a comprehensive
update of the earlier CIGRE brochure 204 (2002). CIGRE brochure 530 (2013) is a
guide for conducting “transformer factory capability assessments ”, that is, for
transformer supplier quali ﬁcation and development. It was a new departure for
CIGRE, and of special interest to users purchasing transformers or reactors from
unfamiliar suppliers.
CIGRE working group A2.42 was established to continue the work of A2.36 on
transformer transportation (CIGRE Brochure 673 2016). CIGRE working group
A2.58 was then established to continue the work of A2.36 and A2.42 on transformer
vii
and reactor installation, pre-commissioning, and trial operation. Their ﬁnal report
was in preparaion at the time this Green Book was published.
Transformer Procurement in the Future
CIGRE’s work has increasingly been focused on two related challenges – ensuring
universal access to reliable electricity and ensuring the sustainability of the electric-
ity supply. These two challenges cannot be addressed separately, as universal access
to reliable electricity is critically dependent on better integration of distributed
renewable energy resources. Aspects of these challenges of special relevance for
transformers and reactors include (Hatziargyriou and de Siqueira 2020):
 Improved transformers for solar integration
 Improved transformers for wind integration
 Higher AC and DC transmission voltages, to allow integration of renewable
energy resources in remote areas
 Increased use of phase-shifting transformers, to control power ﬂows
 Site assembly of large power transformers, also to allow integration of renewable
energy resources in remote areas
 Development of alternative technologies to the conventional oil-immersed trans-
former or reactor
 Better control of audible sound levels
 Better control of losses
 Improved transformer and reactor life management
 Improved designs to cope with variations in system voltage
 Improved designs to cope with variations in system frequency
Some of the transformer and reactor technologies developed to meet these
challenges are suf ﬁciently mature to be included in this Green Book. The following
material is of special relevance:
 Improved transformers for solar and wind integration

This Green Book is dedicated by CIGRE Study Committee A2 to the memory of
Arthur Conway “Sam” Hall, who did so much in his long career to improve
transformer procurement practices.
Sam Hall was born in 1932 at Westerhope, near to Newcastle-upon-Tyne in the
industrial northeast of England. He began work as an apprentice with CA Parsons, a
local transformer manufacturer, in 1948 at the age of 16. After completing his
apprenticeship, he studied high-voltage engineering at Heriot-Watt University in
Edinburgh, returning to CA Parsons in the design department. He was an early
pioneer of computer-aided design for transformers. He left CA Parsons in 1965 to
join the Central Electricity Generating Board at the peak of the development of the
400 kV transmission network in Great Britain. Here, he made important contribu-
tions to improving transformer speci ﬁcations, design review, and factory acceptance
testing. He also made important improvements in transformer life management, and
was an early pioneer of the use of frequency response analysis for transformer
diagnosis. On the breaking up of the Central Electricity Generating Board, he joined
National Grid. In 1995, at the age of 63, he retired from National Grid and founded
his own consultancy business. He continued to work as a consultant until shortly
before his death in 2015, making important contributions to the development of
HVDC in India and the reliability of wind turbine transformers in Great Britain.
Sam Hall gave generously of his time and expertise to CIGRE, attending most if
not all the colloquiums and sessions. Of his many contributions to CIGRE, perhaps
the most important was in convening working group 12.15 on transformer speci ﬁ-
cations. This represented the ﬁrst attempt by CIGRE to bring transformer users and
manufacturers together to improve the quality of transformers by improving the
procurement process. Sam Hall was able to bring his experience in both transformer
design and construction and in transformer life management together to make this
xi
working group a success. He later made a very important contribution to working
group A2.36, which looked at the transformer procurement process more widely. It is
for these contributions to CIGRE, and the industry more widely, that this Green
Book is dedicated to his memory.
Outside work, Sam Hall was a well-known sailor and a well-known supporter of
the Royal National Institute for the Blind. He was survived by his wife Dorothy, his
children Michael and Kerry, and his ﬁve grandchildren. At his funeral, his son
Michael said, “We shall not cry for his life that has ended, but smile for his life
lived.”
Prof. Paul Jarman

About the Editors
Gilson M. Bastos was born in Brazil in 1954 and graduated in electrical engineer-
ing from the Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro in 1979. He joined Furnas
Centrais Eletricas, one of the largest utilities in Brazil, working as a transformer
engineer and electrical equipment engineer up to 2007. From 2007 to 2013, he
worked in the renewable energy area as manager of the planning department. From
2014 until his retirement from Furnas in 2017, he oversaw all transmission projects.
Following his retirement from Furnas, he joined MSG Transmission, where he is
responsible for new 500 kV transmission projects.
Gilson has been an active member of CIGRE for many years. He was a member
of working groups A2.27 on condition monitoring facilities, A2/B4.28 on HVDC
transformers, and A2.37 on transformer reliability. Gilson was also regular member
for Brazil on SC A2 between 2014 and 2020.
Tom Breckenridge was born in Greenock, Scotland, in 1955. He studied electrical
and electronic engineering at the University of Glasgow between 1973 and 1977. He
joined the South of Scotland Electricity Board in 1978, initially as an operational
engineer within the distribution ﬁeld. A move to transmission substation design
followed in 1996, where he also assumed the role as principal transformer expert for
Scottish Power responsible for speci ﬁcation purchasing and approval of all trans-
formers. Leaving Scottish Power in 2006, he founded TB TCS Ltd through which he
provides specialist services in the ﬁeld of large power transformers on a global basis,
primarily operating in the procurement area.
He is a registered European engineer, a fellow of the IET, a UK chartered
engineer, and a distinguished member of CIGRE. He was convenor of CIGRE
working group A2-36 on transformer procurement. Tom is chairman designate of
British Standards PEL/14 committee for power transformers and a member of
several IEC maintenance teams under IEC TC14 where he was also IEC convener
for the latest version of IEC/IEEE standard 60076-16 for wind turbine
transformers.
xv
Mike Lamb was born in the USA in 1966. He is currently manager of electric
transmission operations engineering in the power delivery group at Dominion
Energy in Richmond Virginia, USA. He joined Dominion Energy in 1988 and has
held several engineering positions during his career with experience in electric
substation and transmission line design and maintenance, distribution system plan-
ning and operations, and system operations contingency analysis and transmission
open access. Prior to his current position, he was principal engineer in electric
transmission operations engineering responsible for the technical oversight of the
power transformer procurement process in support of all Dominion Energy ’s busi-
ness units. Mike now leads a team of specialized engineers responsible for major
electric transmission equipment speci ﬁcations; system analysis, technical investiga-
tions and root cause analyses, and providing analysis and guidance for emerging
technological challenges.
He became a member of CIGRE in 2007. Mike was a member of CIGRE working
group A2.36 on transformer procurement and secretary of CIGRE working group
A2.48 on shunt reactors, and he is secretary of CIGRE working group A2.58 on
installation and pre-commissioning. He has been an active member of CIGRE
USNC and was a recipient in 2018 of the Attwood Associate Award.
Tara-Lee MacArthur studied electrical engineering at Queensland University of
Technology from 2008 to 2011, graduating with a BEng. She works for an Australian
energy utility as a substation design standards engineer and is noted for her work on
power transformer speciﬁcation and design and transformer life management. She is a
member of the CIGRE Australia A2 mirror panel (since 2015) and director of the
CIGRE Australia Board (since 2020). She has been an active member within CIGRE
internationally as secretary of CIGRE Working Group A2.49 between 2016 and 2019
and has been chair of A2 AG.2 on tutorials since 2020. She is a registered professional
engineer in Queensland, Australia.
Simon Ryder was born in England in 1973. He studied engineering science at St
John’s College, Oxford University, between 1992 and 1996. He worked for GEC
Alsthom and later Alstom, between 1997 and 2003, in transformer design, development,
and eventually research. He is known for his work on thermal characteristics of trans-
formers and frequency response analysis (FRA). He joined Doble in 2003, initially
working mainly on transformer life management. Since 2009, he has worked mainly on
transformer procurement, especially supplier qualiﬁcation and development.
He is a senior member of IEEE-PES, a fellow of IET, and a chartered engineer. He
was a member of CIGRE working groups A2.36 on transformer procurement, D1/A2.47
on advances in DGA interpretation, and A2.58 on transformer installation,
pre-commissioning, and trial operation, and was convenor of CIGRE working group
A2.48 on shunt reactors. He was chairman of CIGRE Committee A2 on power trans-
formers and reactors between 2016 and 2020. He is editor-in-chief of this Green Book.
